root.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
root.pub-comments: This is an amalgamation of subtrees of the pidgin and creole trees provided in Ethnologue. It has been broken into regions for ease of searching.

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: The basilect (extreme varieties) and Standard English are inherently unintelligible to each other's speakers (Voegelin and Voegelin, LePage, Adler). It may be partly intelligible to speakers of Cameroon Pidgin and Krio of Sierra Leone, spoken by descendants of Jamaicans repatriated between 1787 and 1860. Inherently intelligible to speakers of creoles in Panama and Costa Rica. Reported to be very close to Belize Creole, close to Grenada, Saint Vincent, different from Tobago, very different from Guyana, Barbados, Leeward and Windward islands. Lexical similarity 25% with Guyanese, 13% with Belizean, 9% with Trinidadian, 8% with Barbadian, 5% with Nicaraguan.

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: Jamaican migrants settled in Limón about the middle of the 19th century, as they also did in Panama, so those varieties are close. Some say they do not understand Islander Creole English of San Andrés. Most speakers have limited comprehension of Standard English.
child.alt-names: Southwestern Caribbean Creole English
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Costa Rica, east of San José, principally along the railroad between Siquirres and Limón, and south of Limón along the road.

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: Influences from both eastern and western Caribbean Creole English.
child.alt-names: Southwestern Caribbean Creole English
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Panama, Bocas del Toro, Colón, and Rio Abajo in Panama City.

child.alt-names: Patwa, Patois, Bongo Talk, Quashie Talk, Southwestern Caribbean Creole English
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Jamaicia, also spoken in Canada, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Panama, United Kingdom, USA.

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: There is reported to be a 'deep Creole'. Very close to Belize Creole English.
child.alt-names: San Andrés Creole, Bende
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Columbia, San Andrés and Providencia Islands.

child.pub-comments: Jamaican Creole is different in orthography and grammar.

child.pub-comments: In British Virgin Islands is said to coexist with English in a fairly stable diglossic relationship (Holm 1989:455).

child.geography: Netherlands Antilles, Southern St. Maarten, Saba, St. Eustatius.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: U. S. Virgin Islands. Also spoken in British Virgin Islands, Netherlands Antilles.

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: May have some French influence, although the former French creole used here is virtually gone. J. Holm says it is the only folk language (1989:457). Closest to Guyana, Tobago.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines.

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: There is a basilectal variety spoken in a fishing village (Roy 1986). The speech of the poor and less educated is similar to the mesolect in nearby countries. Increasingly influenced by USA rather than United Kingdom English (Todd and Hancock 1986). Fewer than 20 lexical items are traceable to African origin (Niles 1980:148). Shares lexical features with Caribbean creoles.
child.alt-names: Barbadian Creole English
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Barbados

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: M. Alleyne says it is a post-creole English with French creole influence, no longer a creole. R. Kephart says Carriacou is a creole English. J. Holm says the creole predominates in Grenada (1989:458). Closest to Trinidad and Barbados.

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Grenada

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: Slightly intelligible with Jamaican and perhaps Bahamas creoles. May be close to English Creoles of the Virgin Islands and Netherlands Antilles.

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: Separated from coastal Sea Islands Creole between 1690 and 1760. Similar to Sea Islands Creole of USA and Bahamas Creole. Lexical similarity 90% with Sea Islands Creole. No speakers left in Oklahoma. Probably absorbed by Bahamian on Andros Island and by Spanish in Cuba.

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.alt-names: Afro-Seminole, Afro-Seminol Criollo
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Mexico, Nacimiento de los Negros, Coahuila.

child.alt-names: Afro-Seminole, Seminole, Black Seminole
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: USA. Bracketville, Texas. Also spoken in Mexico.

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: Intelligibility with Sea Islands Creole good. Very close to Sea Islands Creole and Afro-Seminole of USA (Ian Hancock). The major differences with Sea Islands are in phonology, a few words, regional expressions, and a few grammatical differences (verbal markers). There is a spectrum of varieties from Standard USA English usage to the creole (Todd and Hancock 1986).
child.alt-names: Bahamian Creole English, Bahamian Dialect
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Bahamas, also spoken in USA.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: This variety has not been studied, but it may be related to Bahamas Creole (Holm 1989:489).
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Turks and Caicos Islands

child.pub-comments: Intelligibility of Saint Lucia Creole is 78%, of Karipúna Creole of Brazil 77%. Some decreolization is taking place.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Linguistic influences from Wolof (Benjamin 1956), Fon, and Éwé (C. Lefebvre) of West Africa.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Haiti, throughout the country. Also spoken in Bahamas, Canada, Cayman Islands, Dominican Republic, French Guiana, Guadeloupe, Puerto Rico, USA. St. Maartin, St. Barths, and Guadeloupe.

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: Not intelligible with Standard French. Saint Lucia Creole French is close to Dominican Creole French (97% to 99% intelligibility). Goodman (1964) says all French creoles of the Caribbean are somewhat inherently intelligible to each other's speakers. The dialect of Dominica is virtually the same as Saint Lucia.

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.alt-names: Patois, Patwa, Lesser Antillean Creole French
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Trinidad and Tobago. Trinidad, villages of the Northern Range, fishing communities in the islands, and coastal settlements along the peninsula to the west of the capital especially (I. Hancock, ms.).

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: The dialect of Dominica is virtually the same as Saint Lucia. Loanwords from Island Carib and Arawak.
child.alt-names: Lesser Antillean Creole French, Patwa, Patois, Kwèyòl
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Dominica

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: The same as, or similar to, that spoken in Saint Lucia (M. Alleyne).

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.geography: Grenada. Carriacou Island. On northern Grenada Island it is in scattered pockets, mainly in rural areas.

child.alt-names: Patwa, Patois, Kwéyòl, Lesser Antillean Creole French.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Saint Lucia, also spoken in Dominica, France, Grenada, Guyana, Trinidad and Tobago.

child.tree-val: Central American Pidgins and Creoles: Ethnologue 2005
child.pub-comments: St. Barth Creole is distinct in grammatical, phonological, and lexical features, and may not be a dialect (J. Maher 1989). Comprehension of Saint Lucia Creole is 89%.

child.geography: Marie Galante islands

child.pub-comments: St. Barth Creole is distinct in grammatical, phonological, and lexical features, and may not be a dialect (J. Maher 1989).
